awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Spatial Modeling and Computation of Cell Signaling in Cell-to-Cell Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
Cell-to-cell communication is fundamental to cell and system functions. Proper communication between cells relies upon precise control and coordination of extracellular and intracellular signaling, as well as the induced cellular responses such as cell morphogenesis. This project is to study cell-to-cell communication through yeast mating system using mathematical modeling and will be conducted in close collaboration with experimentalists. The project will develop the models and the computational framework for a multi-cell environment that includes complex extracellular and intracellular signaling networks and the cell morphological changes. Numerical methods will be developed to meet the computational modeling challenges. 

Cells interact with their environment or with other cells through sensing and making responses such as cell movement and cell shape change. These processes require precise coordination of intricate cellular networks and the resulting responses. This project will use mathematical modeling and computation to examine the interaction between cells and the underlying networks. The models and computational framework developed in this research can be applied to other systems, such as neural and immune systems, in which cell-to-cell communication is central to their function. Therefore, this project can aid medical research. The research in this project will be integrated with educational activities in computational and mathematical methods, with the aim of training undergraduate and graduate students for interdisciplinary research in mathematical biology.

por.por_cntn:
Cell-to-cell communication is fundamental to cell and system functions. Proper communication between cells relies upon precise control and coordination of extracellular and intracellular signaling, as well as the induced cellular responses such as cell morphogenesis. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project aimed to develop a comprehensive computational and modeling framework to advance the system-level understanding of cell-to-cell communication, and develop undergraduate and graduate educational activities integrated with proposed research.

 

During the past five years, we studied cell-to-cell communication during budding yeast mating process through the following projects. First, we investigated how the spatial distribution of extracellular signaling molecules, the intracellular signal transduction pathway and cell shape change collectively influence cell-cell interaction. We explored how the performance objectives of the system including sensitivity, adaptivity and noise attenuation, are achieved during mating. Second, we studied the mechanisms underlying differential cell morphologies in yeast mating, and identified molecular interactions responsible for the shape differences. Third, to overcome the computational challenges in the first two projects, we developed efficient numerical methods for calculating the steady state of convection-diffusion system.

 

Our works have been disseminated to the public through journal publication and presentations in workshops and conferences. Our findings could be potentially important to applications in human health, especially in neural system, immune system and angiogenesis. Our research program has been integrated with education activities, including (1) an undergraduate interdisciplinary training program, which trained 16 undergraduate students in total; (2) graduate student working group; which trained numerous graduate students and postdoctoral fellows; (3) graduate student mentorship, for which the PI trained 4 Ph.D. students and 2 master students. These trained undergraduate and graduate students have contributed to the workforce in the field of math biology.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2019
Modified by: Ching-Shan Chou
